Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A battery, a resistor, a capacitor, an inductor, and two switches are connected in a circuit, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. Initially, both switches are open and the capacitor is uncharged. At time <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, Switch <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> is closed.

(a)

i. Starting with an appropriate application of Kirchhoff’s loop rule, derive, but do NOT solve, a differential equation that could be used to find the current <math alttext="I" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>I</mi></math> in the circuit as a function of time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math> after Switch <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> is closed. Take the positive direction of current to be clockwise around the circuit. Express the differential equation in terms of <math alttext="I" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>I</mi></math>, <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math>, <math alttext="script uppercase E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ɛ</mi></math>, <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math>, <math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>L</mi></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A battery, a resistor, a capacitor, an inductor, and two switches are connected in a circuit, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. Initially, both switches are open and the capacitor is uncharged. At time <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, Switch <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> is closed.

(a)

i. Starting with an appropriate application of Kirchhoff’s loop rule, derive, but do NOT solve, a differential equation that could be used to find the current <math alttext="I" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>I</mi></math> in the circuit as a function of time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math> after Switch <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> is closed. Take the positive direction of current to be clockwise around the circuit. Express the differential equation in terms of <math alttext="I" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>I</mi></math>, <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math>, <math alttext="script uppercase E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ɛ</mi></math>, <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math>, <math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>L</mi></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

ii. Using the differential equation from part (a)(i), derive an expression for <math alttext="I" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>I</mi></math> as a function of <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math> for <math alttext="t greater than 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math>, <math alttext="script uppercase E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ɛ</mi></math>, <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math>, <math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>L</mi></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate. Begin your derivation by writing a fundamental physics principle or an equation from the reference information.

A long time after Switch <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> is closed, the current in the circuit can be considered to be at its steady-state value. Switch <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math> is then closed, immediately after which Switch <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> is opened. This occurs at time <math alttext="t equals t sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></math>.

iii. On the axes in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, sketch a graph of the charge <math alttext="Q sub top plate" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>Q</mi><mrow><mtext>top</mtext><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>plate</mtext></mrow></msub></math> on the top plate of the capacitor as a function of time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math> for times after Switch <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math> is closed. On the horizontal axis, indicate a relevant, characteristic time for the graph in terms of <math alttext="script uppercase E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ɛ</mi></math>, <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math>, <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>C</mi></math>, <math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>L</mi></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

(b) Derive an expression for <math alttext="delta V sub max" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>V</mi><mi>max</mi></msub></math>, the maximum potential difference attained by the capacitor after time <math alttext="t equals t sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></msub></math>. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="script uppercase E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ɛ</mi></math>, <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math>, <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>C</mi></math>, <math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>L</mi></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate. Begin your derivation by writing a fundamental physics principle or an equation from the reference information.
